definitions.definition: The process by which green plants and some other organisms use sunlight to synthesize foods from carbon dioxide and water.
definitions.example: Photosynthesis in plants generally involves the green pigment chlorophyll.

definitions.definition: A type of cell division that results in two daughter cells each having the same number and kind of chromosomes as the parent nucleus.
definitions.example: Mitosis is essential for the growth and repair of tissues.

definitions.definition: The force that attracts a body toward the center of the earth, or toward any other physical body having mass.
definitions.example: The gravity of the moon causes the ocean tides on Earth.

definitions.definition: A substance produced by a living organism which acts as a catalyst to bring about a specific biochemical reaction.
definitions.example: Digestive enzymes break down food in the human stomach.

definitions.definition: The rate of change of velocity per unit time.
definitions.example: The car increased its acceleration to overtake the truck.

definitions.definition: The maximum extent of a vibration or oscillation, measured from the position of equilibrium.
definitions.example: A loud sound has a larger amplitude than a soft sound.

definitions.definition: The basic unit of a chemical element, consisting of a nucleus and one or more electrons.
definitions.example: An atom is the smallest unit of ordinary matter.

definitions.definition: The rate of change of angular displacement with respect to time.
definitions.example: The spinning wheel had a high angular velocity.

definitions.definition: A force acting opposite to the relative motion of any object moving with respect to a surrounding fluid.
definitions.example: Parachutes work by increasing air resistance.

definitions.definition: A principle stating that a body immersed in a fluid is buoyed up by a force equal to the weight of the displaced fluid.
definitions.example: Archimedes' principle explains why ships float.

definitions.definition: An electric current that reverses its direction at regular intervals.
definitions.example: The electricity in homes is supplied as alternating current (AC).

definitions.definition: A positively charged particle consisting of two protons and two neutrons, emitted in radioactive decay.
definitions.example: Alpha particles are emitted during the decay of uranium.

definitions.definition: The angle through which an object moves on a circular path.
definitions.example: The angular displacement of the fan blade was 90 degrees.

definitions.definition: The electrode where oxidation occurs, often the positive terminal in a device.
definitions.example: Electrons flow toward the anode in a galvanic cell.

definitions.definition: A point of maximum amplitude on a standing wave.
definitions.example: At the antinode, the wave's displacement is greatest.

definitions.definition: The base unit of electric current in the International System of Units (SI).
definitions.example: The fuse is rated for 5 amperes of current.

definitions.definition: The gradual loss in intensity of any kind of flux through a medium.
definitions.example: Sound attenuation in air increases with distance.

definitions.definition: The quantity of rotation of a body, measured by the product of its moment of inertia and angular velocity.
definitions.example: A spinning skater pulls in her arms to conserve angular momentum.

definitions.definition: The pressure exerted by the weight of the atmosphere.
definitions.example: Atmospheric pressure decreases with altitude.

definitions.definition: A device that generates alternating current by converting mechanical energy into electrical energy.
definitions.example: The car’s alternator recharges the battery while the engine runs.

definitions.definition: The number of protons in the nucleus of an atom.
definitions.example: Hydrogen has an atomic number of 1.

definitions.definition: The mass of an atom, typically expressed in atomic mass units (amu).
definitions.example: The atomic mass of carbon is about 12 amu.

definitions.definition: The number of constituent particles in one mole of a substance, approximately 6.022 × 10²³.
definitions.example: Avogadro's constant is crucial in mole calculations.

definitions.definition: A sudden and massive increase in current due to ionization in semiconductors.
definitions.example: The diode failed due to the avalanche effect.

definitions.definition: A device used to transmit or receive electromagnetic waves.
definitions.example: The radio uses an antenna to receive signals.

definitions.definition: A material that takes in energy, especially radiation or sound.
definitions.example: Lead is often used as a radiation absorber.

definitions.definition: A thermodynamic process in which no heat is exchanged with the surroundings.
definitions.example: In an adiabatic expansion, the system does work on the surroundings.

definitions.definition: The rate of change of angular velocity.
definitions.example: The disc had a uniform angular acceleration.

definitions.definition: The scientific study of celestial objects, space, and the universe as a whole.
definitions.example: Astronomy helps us understand stars and planets.

definitions.definition: A spectrum of absorbed light or radiation, showing dark lines or bands.
definitions.example: The absorption spectrum of hydrogen reveals its energy levels.

definitions.definition: A device that converts energy into mechanical motion.
definitions.example: Robots use actuators to move their limbs.

definitions.definition: A scientific theory stating that all matter is composed of atoms.
definitions.example: Atomic theory forms the foundation of modern chemistry and physics.

definitions.definition: The ability or tendency of an object to float in a fluid.
definitions.example: Wood floats on water because of its buoyancy.

definitions.definition: A device that stores chemical energy and converts it into electrical energy.
definitions.example: The torch stopped working because the battery was dead.

definitions.definition: An instrument measuring atmospheric pressure.
definitions.example: The barometer showed a sudden drop in pressure, indicating a storm.

definitions.definition: A subatomic particle made up of three quarks, including protons and neutrons.
definitions.example: Protons and neutrons are baryons.

definitions.definition: The temperature at which a liquid turns into vapor.
definitions.example: Water has a boiling point of 100°C at sea level.

definitions.definition: A region in space where the gravitational pull is so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape.
definitions.example: The black hole in the galaxy's center pulls in nearby matter.

definitions.definition: A stream of particles or waves, such as a beam of light or electrons.
definitions.example: The laser emits a focused beam of light.

definitions.definition: Low-level natural radiation present in the environment.
definitions.example: We are constantly exposed to background radiation from space and the Earth.

definitions.definition: A type of radioactive decay in which a beta particle is emitted.
definitions.example: Beta decay changes a neutron into a proton or vice versa.

definitions.definition: The energy required to separate a nucleus into its component nucleons.
definitions.example: The binding energy explains the stability of atomic nuclei.

definitions.definition: The distance a vehicle travels while slowing to a stop after the brakes are applied.
definitions.example: Braking distance increases with speed.

definitions.definition: A state where opposing forces are equal, resulting in equilibrium.
definitions.example: The seesaw is in balance when both sides are level.

definitions.definition: A law stating that the pressure of a gas is inversely proportional to its volume at constant temperature.
definitions.example: According to Boyle’s Law, decreasing volume increases pressure.

definitions.definition: The basic unit of information in computing and digital communications, representing a binary value of 0 or 1.
definitions.example: Each pixel in the image is stored using several bits.

definitions.definition: The total amount of electric charge a battery can store.
definitions.example: A higher battery capacity means longer device usage.

definitions.definition: The range of frequencies within a given band, especially used for transmitting a signal.
definitions.example: Higher bandwidth allows faster data transfer.

definitions.definition: A strip made of two different metals that expands at different rates when heated.
definitions.example: Bimetallic strips are used in thermostats.

definitions.definition: A model of the atom in which electrons orbit the nucleus at specific distances.
definitions.example: The Bohr model explains the spectral lines of hydrogen.

definitions.definition: A principle stating that an increase in fluid speed leads to a decrease in pressure.
definitions.example: Bernoulli's principle explains how airplanes generate lift.

definitions.definition: The rapid vaporization of a liquid when it reaches its boiling point.
definitions.example: Boiling water produces steam.

definitions.definition: A device or material that reduces shock or protects from damage.
definitions.example: The bumper acts as a buffer in car collisions.

definitions.definition: A device for slowing or stopping motion, especially in vehicles.
definitions.example: The driver applied the brake to avoid hitting the car ahead.

definitions.definition: A consistent voltage applied to a device to operate it in a certain mode.
definitions.example: The diode requires a forward bias to conduct current.

definitions.definition: An instrument for measuring radiation by detecting heat.
definitions.example: Astronomers use bolometers to detect faint thermal emissions.

definitions.definition: A law that describes the magnetic field generated by a current-carrying wire.
definitions.example: The Biot–Savart Law helps calculate magnetic fields around wires.

definitions.definition: The amount of light emitted or reflected by an object.
definitions.example: The brightness of the bulb depends on its power rating.

definitions.definition: A fundamental unit in the SI system from which all other units are derived.
definitions.example: The meter is the base unit of length.

definitions.definition: The number of bits transmitted per second in a digital network.
definitions.example: Streaming video at high quality requires a higher bit rate.

definitions.definition: A device that increases power, pressure, or signal strength.
definitions.example: The amplifier acts as a booster for the radio signal.

definitions.definition: The ability of a system to store electric charge.
definitions.example: The capacitance of a capacitor determines how much charge it can hold.

definitions.definition: An electronic component used to store energy in an electric field.
definitions.example: The capacitor in the circuit stores charge and releases it when needed.

definitions.definition: The electrode at which reduction occurs; negatively charged in a discharging battery.
definitions.example: Electrons enter the device through the cathode.

definitions.definition: A force that acts on a body moving in a circular path and is directed toward the center of the circle.
definitions.example: Centripetal force keeps the car on its circular track.

definitions.definition: A closed path through which an electric current flows or may flow.
definitions.example: The circuit was broken, stopping the flow of current.

definitions.definition: The transfer of heat or electricity through a substance.
definitions.example: Metal is a good conductor of heat due to conduction.

definitions.definition: A material that allows the flow of electrical current or heat.
definitions.example: Copper is widely used as an electrical conductor.

definitions.definition: A principle stating that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed.
definitions.example: The conservation of energy is a fundamental concept in physics.

definitions.definition: A lens that is thicker in the middle than at the edges and converges light rays.
definitions.example: A convex lens is used in magnifying glasses.

definitions.definition: A lens that is thinner in the middle and diverges light rays.
definitions.example: Concave lenses are used to correct short-sightedness.

definitions.definition: The region in a longitudinal wave where particles are closest together.
definitions.example: Sound travels in compressions and rarefactions.

definitions.definition: A property of a body that experiences a force in an electric field.
definitions.example: Electrons carry a negative charge.

definitions.definition: The flow of electric charge in a conductor.
definitions.example: The electric current flows from the battery through the wires.

definitions.definition: A variable that is kept constant in an experiment.
definitions.example: Temperature was a control variable in the physics experiment.

definitions.definition: An apparent force that acts outward on a body moving around a center.
definitions.example: Centrifugal force is felt in a spinning ride.

definitions.definition: A safety device that stops the flow of current in an overloaded circuit.
definitions.example: The circuit breaker tripped when the iron short-circuited.

definitions.definition: Energy stored in the bonds of chemical compounds.
definitions.example: Chemical energy in food is converted into mechanical energy in the body.

definitions.definition: A loop or series of loops of wire, often used in electromagnets and inductors.
definitions.example: A coil in the motor helps generate a magnetic field.

definitions.definition: A device used to detect ionizing radiation by observing condensation trails.
definitions.example: A cloud chamber shows the paths of alpha particles.

definitions.definition: The SI unit of electric charge.
definitions.example: One coulomb is the charge transported by a current of one ampere in one second.

definitions.definition: The minimum angle of incidence at which total internal reflection occurs.
definitions.example: Light hitting the surface at the critical angle reflects completely.

definitions.definition: Capable of being compressed or reduced in volume.
definitions.example: Gases are compressible unlike liquids.

definitions.definition: A numerical value that represents a physical property or relation.
definitions.example: The coefficient of friction depends on the surfaces in contact.

definitions.definition: A tool used to grip and turn objects such as nuts and bolts.
definitions.example: The crescent wrench was used to tighten the nut in the physics lab.

definitions.definition: The transfer of heat by the movement of fluids (liquids or gases).
definitions.example: Warm air rises due to convection currents.

definitions.definition: The highest point of a wave.
definitions.example: The distance between two crests is the wavelength.

definitions.definition: A force that squeezes or shortens a material.
definitions.example: Pushing both ends of a spring creates a compression force.

definitions.definition: The point where the mass of a body or system is concentrated.
definitions.example: The center of mass of a uniform rod is at its midpoint.

definitions.definition: A group in an experiment that does not receive the experimental treatment.
definitions.example: The control group was used for comparison in the heat conduction experiment.

definitions.definition: The mass of a substance per unit volume.
definitions.example: The density of water is 1 g/cm³.

definitions.definition: The change in position of an object in a specific direction.
definitions.example: The car's displacement was 100 meters east.

definitions.definition: A force that opposes an object's motion through a fluid.
definitions.example: Airplanes are designed to reduce air drag.

definitions.definition: The bending of waves around obstacles or through openings.
definitions.example: Light undergoes diffraction when it passes through a narrow slit.

definitions.definition: An apparent change in the frequency of a wave caused by motion between the source and observer.
definitions.example: The Doppler Effect explains why an ambulance siren changes pitch as it passes.

definitions.definition: An electronic component that allows current to flow in only one direction.
definitions.example: Diodes are used in circuits to prevent reverse current.

definitions.definition: A measurable extent of a physical quantity, such as length, time, or mass.
definitions.example: Length, time, and mass are examples of dimensions in physics.

definitions.definition: The flow of electric charge through a medium.
definitions.example: Lightning is a natural example of electrical discharge.

definitions.definition: A unit used to measure the intensity of a sound.
definitions.example: Normal conversation is around 60 decibels.

definitions.definition: A device used to identify or measure physical quantities.
definitions.example: Smoke detectors are used for safety in buildings.

definitions.definition: The process of a substance spreading out to evenly fill its container or environment.
definitions.example: The diffusion of gases is faster at higher temperatures.

definitions.definition: A material that does not conduct electricity but can support an electrostatic field.
definitions.example: Capacitors use dielectric materials to store charge.

definitions.definition: A device used to detect the presence of a specific type of energy or matter.
definitions.example: A metal detector senses metallic objects underground.

definitions.definition: The study of forces and motion of objects.
definitions.example: Newton's laws form the basis of classical dynamics.

definitions.definition: Involving or relating to the use of computer technology or binary signals.
definitions.example: Digital thermometers provide quick temperature readings.

definitions.definition: An electric current flowing in one direction only.
definitions.example: Batteries produce direct current (DC).

definitions.definition: Electric current caused by the movement of charge carriers from high to low concentration.
definitions.example: Semiconductors use diffusion current in their operation.

definitions.definition: The gradual reduction of amplitude in oscillating systems.
definitions.example: Shock absorbers in cars provide damping.

definitions.definition: A decrease in the speed or velocity of an object.
definitions.example: The car experienced deceleration when the brakes were applied.

definitions.definition: A form of magnetism that causes a material to repel a magnetic field.
definitions.example: Bismuth is known for its strong diamagnetism.

definitions.definition: Reflection of light from a rough surface, scattering in many directions.
definitions.example: Paper exhibits diffuse reflection rather than a clear image.

definitions.definition: The maximum electric field a material can withstand without breaking down.
definitions.example: Dielectric strength is critical in insulating materials.

definitions.definition: The scattering of light as it passes through a translucent material.
definitions.example: Frosted glass causes diffusion of light.

definitions.definition: A change in shape due to the application of force.
definitions.example: Elastic deformation occurs when a spring is stretched.

definitions.definition: The process of spreading something over an area, such as energy or charge.
definitions.example: The electric charge distribution affects the field strength.

definitions.definition: The average velocity of electrons in a conductor due to an electric field.
definitions.example: Drift velocity is proportional to current.

definitions.definition: A type of matter that does not emit light or energy and is detectable only through gravitational effects.
definitions.example: Dark matter makes up a large part of the universe.

definitions.definition: A region in a magnetic material where the magnetization is in a uniform direction.
definitions.example: Domains align in a magnetized iron bar.

definitions.definition: A form of energy resulting from the existence of charged particles such as electrons or protons.
definitions.example: Electricity powers lights and appliances in homes.

definitions.definition: The capacity to do work or cause physical change.
definitions.example: Kinetic energy increases with the speed of an object.

definitions.definition: A magnet created by passing an electric current through a coil of wire.
definitions.example: Electromagnets are used in electric bells and motors.

definitions.definition: The range of all types of electromagnetic radiation.
definitions.example: The electromagnetic spectrum includes radio waves, visible light, and X-rays.

definitions.definition: The flow of electric charge through a conductor.
definitions.example: Electric current is measured in amperes.

definitions.definition: A region around a charged object where other charges experience a force.
definitions.example: An electric field surrounds every charged particle.

definitions.definition: The amount of electric potential energy per unit charge at a point.
definitions.example: Electric potential is measured in volts.

definitions.definition: A physical property of matter that causes it to experience a force in an electric field.
definitions.example: Electrons have a negative electric charge.

definitions.definition: A conductor through which electricity enters or leaves an object, substance, or region.
definitions.example: Batteries contain electrodes that facilitate chemical reactions.

definitions.definition: A closed loop or pathway that allows electricity to flow.
definitions.example: A switch opens or closes an electric circuit.

definitions.definition: The energy provided by a source per unit charge.
definitions.example: Electromotive force is measured in volts.

definitions.definition: A negatively charged subatomic particle found outside the nucleus of an atom.
definitions.example: Electrons are involved in electrical conduction.

definitions.definition: The ability of a material to return to its original shape after being stretched or compressed.
definitions.example: Rubber bands have high elasticity.

definitions.definition: The energy stored in an object when it is stretched or compressed.
definitions.example: A stretched spring stores elastic potential energy.

definitions.definition: A state where opposing forces or influences are balanced.
definitions.example: An object at rest on a table is in equilibrium.

definitions.definition: A sound that is reflected off a surface and heard again.
definitions.example: Echoes are heard when sound waves bounce off walls.

definitions.definition: The ratio of useful output to total input in a system.
definitions.example: An engine with high efficiency wastes less energy.

definitions.definition: The rate at which electrical energy is transferred by an electric circuit.
definitions.example: Electric power is measured in watts.

definitions.definition: The process of using electricity to split a compound into its elements.
definitions.example: Water can be split into hydrogen and oxygen by electrolysis.

definitions.definition: A device used to detect electric charge.
definitions.example: An electroscope shows the presence of static electricity.

definitions.definition: A point of zero electric potential used as a common reference in circuits.
definitions.example: Electrical devices are earthed to prevent shock.

definitions.definition: The force between two stationary electric charges.
definitions.example: Electrostatic force can attract or repel objects.

definitions.definition: The opposition that a material offers to the flow of electric current.
definitions.example: Thin wires have more resistance than thick ones.

definitions.definition: The study of electric charges at rest.
definitions.example: Electrostatics explains how objects become charged through friction.

definitions.definition: A device that converts electric energy into heat.
definitions.example: An electric heater is used to warm rooms during cold weather.

definitions.definition: A device that converts electrical energy into mechanical energy.
definitions.example: Electric motors are used in fans and washing machines.

definitions.definition: A fan powered by electricity used for ventilation or cooling.
definitions.example: An electric fan circulates air in a room.

definitions.definition: The increase in size or volume of a substance when heated.
definitions.example: Metals expand when heated due to thermal expansion.

definitions.definition: The process by which a liquid changes into a gas at its surface.
definitions.example: Water in puddles disappears by evaporation.

definitions.definition: A push or pull acting upon an object as a result of its interaction with another object.
definitions.example: A force can change the motion of an object.

definitions.definition: The resistance that one surface or object encounters when moving over another.
definitions.example: Friction between the tires and road helps a car to stop.

definitions.definition: The number of complete oscillations or cycles per second.
definitions.example: Frequency is measured in hertz (Hz).

definitions.definition: A substance that has no fixed shape and yields easily to external pressure; a gas or (especially) a liquid.
definitions.example: Water is a common example of a fluid.

definitions.definition: A safety device consisting of a strip of wire that melts and breaks an electric circuit if the current exceeds a safe level.
definitions.example: The fuse blew due to an electrical overload.

definitions.definition: The distance between the center of a lens or curved mirror and its focus.
definitions.example: The focal length determines the magnifying power of a lens.

definitions.definition: The SI unit of electrical capacitance.
definitions.example: One farad is a very large unit of capacitance.

definitions.definition: A region in which a particular condition exists, especially one in which a force or influence is exerted.
definitions.example: A magnetic field surrounds a magnet.

definitions.definition: The point at which rays or waves meet after reflection or refraction.
definitions.example: A lens brings light to a focus.

definitions.definition: A method of transmitting signals by changing the frequency of a wave.
definitions.example: FM radio uses frequency modulation.

definitions.definition: The motion of a body where gravity is the only force acting upon it.
definitions.example: An object in free fall accelerates at 9.8 m/s² on Earth.

definitions.definition: The pressure at any point within a fluid due to the weight of the fluid above it.
definitions.example: Fluid pressure increases with depth.

definitions.definition: A rule to determine the direction of force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field.
definitions.example: Use Fleming's left hand rule in electric motors.

definitions.definition: A rule used to determine the direction of induced current when a conductor moves in a magnetic field.
definitions.example: Generators work using Fleming’s right hand rule.

definitions.definition: The point at which rays converge after passing through a lens or reflecting from a mirror.
definitions.example: A concave mirror focuses light at its focal point.

definitions.definition: A physical phenomenon where certain materials exhibit strong magnetic properties.
definitions.example: Iron and nickel exhibit ferromagnetism.

definitions.definition: A thin wire that melts to break the circuit when excessive current flows.
definitions.example: Fuse wires are made from alloys with low melting points.

definitions.definition: Imaginary lines used to represent the direction and strength of a field.
definitions.example: Magnetic field lines emerge from the north pole of a magnet.

definitions.definition: An object that is under the influence of gravity.
definitions.example: A falling object accelerates uniformly.

definitions.definition: The study of fluids in motion.
definitions.example: Fluid dynamics explains how air moves around airplane wings.
